{{Infobox scholar | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | name = Nichita P. Smochină | fullname = | other_names = Nikita Smokine | birth_date = {{birth date|1894|3|14}} | birth_place = [[Corjova, Dubăsari|Mahala]], [[Kherson Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1980|12|14|1894|3|14}} | death_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | era = 20th century | region = [[Eastern Europe]] | school_tradition = | main_interests = [[ethnography]], [[folkloristics]], [[historiography]], [[jurisprudence]], [[popular history]], [[Slavic studies]] | notable_ideas = | major_works = | influences = [[Pan Halippa]], [[Nicolae Iorga]] | influenced = }} '''Nichita P. Smochină''' ({{IPA-ro|niˈkita smoˈkinə}}, [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Moldovan Cyrillic alphabet|Moldovan Cyrillic]]: Никита Смокинэ, ''Nikita Smokine''; also known as '''M. Florin'''; March 14, 1894 – December 14, 1980) was a [[Transnistria]]n-born activist, scholar and political figure, especially noted for campaigning on behalf of [[Romanians|ethnic Romanians]] in the [[Soviet Union]]. He was first active in the [[Russian Empire]], serving with distinction in [[World War I]], then in the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], where he earned his reputation as a champion of Transnistrian Romanian interests. An [[Anti-communism|anti-communist]], he narrowly escaped the [[Bolshevik]]s and crossed into [[Romania]], which became his second home. A protégé of historian [[Nicolae Iorga]], Smochină earned his academic credentials and also made himself known internationally as an expert on [[minority rights]]. Beginning in the 1920s, he contributed to historical research, [[ethnography]] and [[folkloristics]], as well as [[jurisprudence]].
During most of [[World War II]], Smochină backed the [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] regime of [[Ion Antonescu]] and paid service to [[Gheorghe Alexianu]]'s [[Transnistria Governorate]]. His scientific work included a recovery of pre-Bolshevik or [[Russophobia|anti-Russian]] [[Romanian folklore]] in Transnistria and beyond. Such activities, along with his exposure of Soviet brutality, made him a wanted man once the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]] took over in Romania. He was eventually captured, sent to prison and deprived of his academic honors. Partly reinstated by the late 1960s, he spent his final decades encouraging the second-generation communist authorities to take a firmer stand against controversial Soviet policies such as "[[Moldovenism]]".
==Biography==
===Origins and early life=== Nichita Smochină was born on the confines of historical [[Moldavia]] and [[Bessarabia]]: the entire Transnistrian region was at the time part of the Russian [[Kherson Governorate]]. As he himself later recounted, the bountiful eastern bank of the [[Dniester]] was home to a thriving Romanian community, or, as he put it, a veritable "Romanian [[California]]".<ref>Datcu, p.15–16</ref> His later research traced the first Romanian presence in that area to the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]], revived by the [[Cossack Hetmanate]]'s border policy, particularly in the 1650s.<ref name="ansdincolo2">{{ro icon}} Alex. N. Smochină, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/dacia/BCUCLUJ_FP_3503_1941_001_0005.pdf "Moldova de dincolo de Nistru"], in ''Dacia'', Nr. 5/1941, p.2 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> According to him, there were two main stages in the migration and resettlement of Moldavian peasants to what became his homeland. The first was under [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Moldavian Prince]] [[George Ducas]] (late 17th century); the second under [[List of Russian rulers|Russian Empress]] [[Catherine the Great]].<ref name="nb104">Băieșu, p.104</ref> Smochină spoke in detail about the Romanian colonies of 18th-century "[[Novorossiya|New Russia]]", that reached as far east as [[Oleksandriya]].<ref name="ansdincolo2"/>
The Smochinăs themselves were descendants of Romanian yeomen (''răzeși''), originally from Moldavia,<ref name="ic(10)237">Constantin (2010), p.237</ref> and reportedly spoke an archaic variant of the [[Romanian language]]. The literary historian [[Al. Husar]], who met Smochină in the 1940s, recalled that his use of the [[Moldavian subdialect of Romanian|eastern dialect]] had the "scent of ages", and "seemed to me a wonder of the Romanian language."<ref name="viahcaract">{{ro icon}} Vasile Iancu, [http://www.romlit.ro/al._husar_caracterul_d_autoritate_sacerdoiului_critic "Al. Husar: 'Caracterul dă autoritate sacerdoțiului critic' "] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714135641/http://www.romlit.ro/al._husar_caracterul_d_autoritate_sacerdoiului_critic# |date=2014-07-14 }}, in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 24/2005</ref>
Smochină's place of birth was [[Corjova, Dubăsari|Mahala]] village, on the eastern, non-Bessarabian, shore of the Dniester.<ref name="annistru">{{ro icon}} Adrian Neculau, [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/opinii/un-roman-de-peste-nistru~ni76rp "Un român de peste Nistru"], in ''[[Ziarul de Iași]]'', March 26, 2011</ref><ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.16; Constantin (2010), p.237; Datcu, p.15</ref> After completing his primary education in [[Dubăsari]] (''Dubossary''), he went to a Russian [[Cadet Corps (Russia)|Cadet school]]<ref name="ic(10)237"/><ref name="annistru"/> and, reportedly, worked as a clerk for Dubăsari Tribunal.<ref name="mttrnistreanul">{{ro icon}} Mihai Tașcă, [http://adevarul.ro/moldova/politica/arhivele-comunismului-vezi-fost-transnistreanul-a-romanizat-moldovenii-1_50acd5bd7c42d5a6638a6e76/index.html "Vezi cine a fost transnistreanul care 'a românizat moldovenii' "], in ''[[Adevărul Moldova]]'', December 22, 2011</ref> He was interested in philology and, with time, became one of the few Romanian experts in the study of [[Old Church Slavonic]].<ref name="annistru"/><ref name="ic(10)238">Constantin (2010), p.238</ref> When World War I erupted, he was serving in the [[Imperial Russian Army]]. His services were rewarded with the [[Order of St. George]] and thus joined the ranks of [[Russian nobility]].<ref name="annistru"/>
The [[February Revolution]] caught Smochină behind the [[Caucasus Campaign|Caucasian Front]]. He was appointed military delegate by a Congress of Peoples in [[Tbilisi]], sent over to [[Petrograd]] for negotiations with the [[Petrograd Soviet|Soviet of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies]] (summer 1917).<ref name="annistru"/><ref name="dnc&al16">Chelaru ''et al.'', p.16</ref> As he later noted, he happened to hear a speech given by [[Vladimir Lenin]], leader of the ultra-revolutionary Bolshevik faction, who was working to topple the [[Russian Provisional Government]]. Smochină was intrigued by Lenin's promise of [[self-determination]] for all of Russia's minorities: "As a Moldavian, I found this issue to be one of greatest interest".<ref name="dnc&al16"/> Smochină was interested in finding out Lenin's level of commitment in this respect, and was received for an interview (as he recalled, this was only possible because one of Lenin's bodyguards was originally from Mahala).<ref name="dnc&al16"/>
According to Smochină's own rendition of the encounter, when asked about his vision on the Moldavian question, Lenin began by stating: "You Moldavians have no interest in fighting on the side of Russia, who for centuries now has been enslaving your kind. Culturally, Moldavians are far more advanced than Russians."<ref name="annistru"/><ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.17; Datcu, p.16</ref> The thing to do, Lenin said, was for Moldavians to take up arms and fight against the two "oppressors": Russia and "landowners' Romania".<ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.16–17; Datcu, p.16</ref> According to Smochină, Lenin openly agreed that Moldavians, Bessarabians and Romanians were in essence [[Controversy over linguistic and ethnic identity in Moldova|the same demonym]]: "Take inspiration from your Romanian blood brothers, but, again, beware of falling into the paws of Romanian [[boyar]] exploiters. [...] all Moldavians are Romanians".<ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.17</ref>
The Bolshevik theorist appears to have incited the Transnistrians and Bessarabians to spread the flame of revolution into "boyar Romania", to "drown the hell out of the [[King of Romania|Romanian king]] and set up a Soviet Romania".<ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.17. Partly rendered in Datcu, p.16</ref> Reportedly, Lenin also urged the Transnistrian delegate to personally to sabotage the war effort on the Caucasus Front, fraternize with the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]] and demand "[[Petrograd formula|peace without annexations or indemnities]]".<ref>Chelaru ''et al.'', p.17; Datcu, p.16–17</ref> As some Romanian historians have noted, "Lenin was not about to curb [a nation's independence], but did not specify in sufficiently clear terms what would happen if they should want to achieve self-determination in any social order other than communism."<ref name="dnc&al16"/>
===Ukrainian deputy and Romanian refugee=== Smochină returned to his place of origin, which was being progressively included in the newly emancipated [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], and began defending the interests of local Romanians. As head of the Mahala ''[[Zemstvo]]'', he tried to prevent the breakdown of social and military order, and narrowly escaped with his life after being pursued by the [[Rumcherod|Bolshevik committees]].<ref name="annistru"/> In December 1917, after a pro-Romanian [[Moldavian Democratic Republic]] had taken root in Bessarabia, he and [[Gheorghe Mare]] were involved with the [[Separatism|separatist]] Congress of Transnistrian Moldavians in [[Tiraspol]], where they flew the [[Flag of Romania|Romanian tricolor]].<ref name="ndtreiculori">{{ro icon}} [[Nicolae Dabija (politician)|Nicolae Dabija]], [http://www.literaturasiarta.md/printpress.php?l=ro&idc=164&idc1=246&id=1850 "''Trei culori...''"], in ''[[Literatura și Arta]]'', October 27, 2011</ref> Smochină stated: "We love our Country so much, that even our [[Romanian icons|icons]] look to Romania."<ref name="ndtreiculori"/> By 1918, he had become Prefect of Tiraspol, then regional envoy to the [[Central Council of Ukraine|Central Rada]] of [[Kiev]], the Ukrainian capital.<ref>Datcu, p.16</ref>
Meanwhile, the [[union of Bessarabia with Romania]] had been effected on the western side of Transnistria, whereas the region itself was made part of the Bolshevik [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]], as the [[Moldavian Autonomous Oblast]]. Smochină's experience of Bolshevik rule was painful, and he recalled [[war communism]] as a trauma: "their entire property taken away, [Romanians in Transnistria] were left naked, downtrodden, worse off than during slavery".<ref name="id17">Datcu, p.17</ref> He escaped Soviet Ukraine on 25 December 1919, and crossed the Dniester into [[Greater Romania]], settling in the former Moldavian capital of [[Iași]].<ref name="annistru"/><ref name="mttrnistreanul"/><ref>Datcu, p.15, 18</ref> According to Smochină, his relatives were exposed to violent Bolshevik reprisals: his father and his female cousin were shot, and the rest were deported to [[Siberia]].<ref name="id18">Datcu, p.18</ref> His wife Agafia escaped with him, but Alexandru was left behind. He joined them in 1922, when a courier commissioned by the father took him over to Iași.<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/> In Romania, the couple had another daughter, baptized Claudia.<ref name="cineseteme">{{ro icon}} Ilie Gulca, Vlad Galin-Corini, [http://www.jurnal.md/ro/news/cine-se-teme-de-nichita-smochina-222611/ "Cine se teme de Nichita Smochină?"], in ''[[Jurnal de Chișinău]]'', July 8, 2012</ref>
While in Iași, Smochină met with jurist Ioan Teodorescu, who helped him enroll at the [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza University|Iași University]] Department of Philosophy and Law.<ref name="annistru"/> He graduated in 1924,<ref name="id15">Datcu, p.15</ref> having by then also studied Psychology with [[Constantin Fedeleș]].<ref name="annistru"/> Smochină joined up with other Transnistrian refugee students during his college term, and militated for increased awareness of their situation; however, he was also a critic of all Romanians arriving from Russia, noting that the [[Education in Russia|Russian education system]] left them poorly trained and superficial.<ref name="annistru"/> He first began associating with a circle of Bessarabian Romanians, and became friends with [[Bessarabian Peasants' Party]] founder [[Pan Halippa]],<ref name="id17"/> heralding humanitarian projects to feed and integrate refugee children.<ref name="annistru"/> It was during those years that Nichita Smochină befriended the senior historian and nationalist politician [[Nicolae Iorga]], a professor at the [[University of Bucharest]]. As early as 1922, he was invited by Iorga's [[Cultural League for the Unity of All Romanians]] to attend their [[Curtea de Argeș]] Congress and speak about Transnistrian grievances.<ref name="annistru"/>
Nichita Smochină also joined the [[Freemasonry in Romania|Romanian Freemasonry]] (the "[[Vasile Alecsandri]]" [[Masonic Lodge|Lodge]]), and, according to his own recollections, lectured other Masons on the plight of Transnistrians.<ref name="id17"/> Smochină met celebrated novelist [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], who was later the [[Grand Master (order)|Grand Master]] of a Freemasonry branch. There was mutual dislike between the two: Smochină accused Sadoveanu of trafficking Freemasonry's services, of not being moved by the fate of Transnistria, and of ultimately destroying other Masons who crossed his path.<ref>Datcu, p.17–18</ref> The Transnistrian activist despised two other figures from Romania's left-wing [[Poporanism|Poporanist]] camp, [[Alexandru Mîță]] and fellow Mason [[Gheorghe Stere]], both of whom he depicted as unprincipled agents of Bolshevism.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.145–146</ref>
This phase coincided with Soviet Transnistria's elevation in administrative status—that is, the establishment of a [[Moldavian ASSR]] on Oblast territory, in the newly proclaimed [[Soviet Union]]. Although refugees were convinced that the Soviet Union was "a [[prison of the peoples]]",<ref name="annistru"/> Smochină and some of his colleagues gave positive review to the move, seeing it as an implicit recognition of Moldavian (and therefore Romanian) self-rule.<ref name="ck181">King, p.181</ref>
===Academic debut and Parisian studies=== From 1924, Smochină's overviews of Transnistrian Romanian life were published with regularity in Iorga's ''[[Ramuri]]'' and ''[[Drum Drept]]'' magazines.<ref name="id15"/> In 1924, the former published his contributions to the ethnography of Romanian communities located between the Dniester and the [[Taurida Governorate]].<ref>{{fr icon}} [[Nicolae Iorga]], [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k55471351.image.r= "Comptes-rendus. J. J. Nistor, ''Românii transnistreni''"], in ''Revue Historique du Sud-Est Européen'', Nr. 4-6/1925, p.159 (digitized by the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ ''Gallica'' digital library])</ref> He was also a contributor to the [[Transylvania]]n review ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', with a 1925 article on Christmas customs as preserved over the Dniester.<ref>{{ro icon}} N. Smochină, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1925_002_051_052.pdf "Crăciunul la moldovenii de peste Nistru"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 51-52, December 1925, p.898–900 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> He was later a manager of ''Tribuna Românilor Transnistrieni'' ("Tribune of the Romanian Transnistrians"), published from 1927 to 1928 in the Bessarabian city of [[Chișinău]].<ref>Datcu, p.15; Kulikovski & Șcelcikova, p.212</ref> The review had contributions from various Bessarabian Romanian activists (Halippa, [[Ștefan Bulat]]) and reported on new cases of human rights abuse in the Moldavian ASSR, such as the forceful relocation of Romanians away from the Dniester.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1928_005_001.pdf "Cărți, reviste, ziare. ''Tribuna Românilor Transnistrieni''"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 1, January 1928, p.17–18 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
Romanian researcher Petre Popescu Gogan describes Smochină as: "a man of The Law, with a calling for human rights and the rights of peoples [...]. Asked to have his say on the issue of [[Minority rights|Minority Rights]], [he] worked in the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] and took part in international congresses on the matter."<ref name="ppgmemento!">{{ro icon}} Petre Popescu Gogan, [http://revista.memoria.ro/?location=view_article&id=351 "Memento!"], in ''Memoria. Revista Gândirii Arestate'', Nr. 28</ref> From 1930 to 1935,<ref>Datcu, p.15, 17</ref> the Transnistrian scholar was in [[France]], where he furthered his studies. He was sponsored by Iorga, who awarded him a scholarship and put him up for the Romanian School of [[Fontenay-aux-Roses]], receiving some more assistance from Halippa.<ref name="id17"/> He focused his research on recovering old texts from sources such as the ''[[Bibliothèque nationale de France|Bibliothèque Nationale]]'' and ''[[Centre d'Études Russes Saint-Georges|Musée Slave]]''.<ref name="annistru"/> In the end, he took a [[Ph.D.]] in History, with [[Ferdinand Lot]] as his [[doctoral advisor]].<ref name="annistru"/> He also began teaching Romanian at ''Société pour la Propagation des Langues Etrangères'', a [[learned society]] funded by the [[University of Paris]].<ref name="annistru"/><ref name="rremigres288">{{fr icon}} R. R., [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k17047h/f129 "Chronique des livres. N. P. Smochina. ''Les émigrés roumains a Paris (1850–1856)''"], in ''[[Revue des Questions Historiques]]'', Nr. 4-5/1935, p.288 (digitized by the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ ''Gallica'' digital library])</ref> At the time, Smochină's first account of the 1917 Lenin interview was published by ''Le Prométhée'', the propaganda outlet for the [[Government of the Democratic Republic of Georgia in Exile|Georgian Government in Exile]].<ref name="dnc&al16"/> He also built contacts with the [[White émigré]] cells, meeting with philosopher [[Nikolai Berdyaev]].<ref name="annistru"/>
Concentrating on informing the world decision-makers about the Transnistrian question, Nichita Smochină was, in 1930, a delegate to [[International Congress of National Minorities]] (a [[League of Nations]] partnership).<ref name="annistru"/><ref>Constantin (2010), p.238; Datcu, p.15</ref> While in [[Paris]], he also set up the Aid Committee for Moldavian Transnistrian Refugees,<ref>Datcu, p.15; King, p.181. See also Constantin (2010), p.238</ref> and campaigned for the international condemnation of reported Soviet mass murders in Transnistria (1932).<ref name="annistru"/> At the time, Smochină's pro-Romania group was challenged by the Soviet-funded Association of Bessarabian Émigrés, whose platform was the whole absorption of Bessarabia into the Moldavian ASSR.<ref>King, p.52</ref>
His scholarly work included a biographical sketch on [[Danylo Apostol|Danylo (Dănilă) Apostol]], the 18th-century Moldavian ''[[Hetman]]'' of [[Left-bank Ukraine]]. It saw print in Romania in 1930, together with his monograph on Moldavian mercenaries fighting on either side of the [[Great Northern War]].<ref name="ansdincolo2"/> The Apostol book was then reprinted in the [[popular history]] collection ''Cunoștințe utile'' ("Useful Knowledge").<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/scoalanoastra/1933/BCUCLUJ_FP_279959_1933_010_003.pdf "Cărți, reviste. N. P. Smochină, ''Dănilă Apostol, Hatmanul Ucrainei''"], in ''Școala Noastră'', Nr. 3/1933, p.88 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> In 1933, Paris' ''Librairie Universitaire J. Gamber'' published his monograph on [[Ion Brătianu]], the founder of [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|Romanian liberalism]], focusing on Brătianu's trial for sedition in 1850s France. The work was reviewed by ''[[Revue des Questions Historiques]]'', which noted that Smochină's style lacked "order" and "clarity", and could prove chronologically inaccurate.<ref name="rremigres288"/> At around that time, the Transnistrian researcher announced that he was also preparing an overview of the Freemasonry's contribution to the [[United Principalities|first union of Romania]] (1859).<ref name="rremigres288"/>
===''Moldova Nouă'' and 1930s research=== In January 1935, Smochină launched a new periodical, titled ''Moldova Nouă'' ("New Moldavia"). Its opening manifesto, expressing a program of the Cultural Association of Transnistrians, promised to provide the Romanian public with a "generic culture" on the Moldavian life in Soviet lands, and to follow the principles of "objectivity, scientific truth [and] the national idea".<ref name="darideseama414-415">{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/tarabarsei/1935/BCUCLUJ_FP_280068_1935_007_004.pdf "Dări de seamă. Reviste și buletine"], in ''Țara Bârsei'', Nr. 4/1935, p.414–415 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> This multilingual review, put out by an editorial headquarters in Iași<ref name="darideseama414-415"/> and the Brawo printing press of [[Bucharest]], only survived until 1936.<ref>Kulikovski & Șcelcikova, p.247</ref> Before closing down, the review had featured his essay ''Republica Moldovenească a Sovietelor'' ("The Moldavian Republic of Soviets"),<ref name="nb104"/> later published by [[Cartea Românească]] as a volume.<ref>King, p.181, 262, 279</ref> In 1935, also with ''Moldova Nouă'', Smochină released his [[French language|French-language]] study ''Les Moldaves de Russie Soviétique'' ("The Moldavians of Soviet Russia"), illustrated with samples of [[Romanian folklore]] from the region—songs about cultural isolation and the impact of [[Russification]].<ref name="nb104"/> He was also contributing to Iorga's academic journal, ''Revue Historique du Sud-Est Européen''. His essays there included the 1936 review of the Moldavian ASSR's standard [[Primer (textbook)|primer]] ''Kuvyntu nostru'', evidencing the [[agitprop]] aspect of [[Education in the Soviet Union|Soviet education]], the vilifying of "''[[kulak]]''" elements in Transnistrian society, and the [[Plagiarism|plagiarizing]] of Romanian textbooks.<ref>{{fr icon}} N. Smochină, [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k55435355/f80.image.r= "Notices. Le roumain en Russie soviétique. Observations sur un livre de lecture"], in ''Revue Historique du Sud-Est Européen'', Nr. 7-9/1936, p.308–312 (digitized by the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ ''Gallica'' digital library])</ref>
Some two years later, Smochină, using the pseudonym ''M. Florin'', began contributing to the Poporanist review ''Însemnări Ieșene'', where he reviewed the work of Bessarabian folklorist [[Tatiana Gălușcă-Crâșmaru]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Maria Trofimov, "Valoarea culegerilor de creație populară orală ale profesoarei Tatiana Gălușcă", in [http://pro-science.asm.md/docs/citc/rezumate_05.pdf ''Conferința Internațională a Tinerilor Cercetători 2005. Rezumatele lucrărilor''], Asociația Tinerilor Cercetători din Moldova ''PRO-Știința'', Chișinău, 2005, p.180. {{ISBN|9975-9716-1-X}}</ref> He followed up in 1939 with ''Din literatura populară a românilor de peste Nistru'' ("Samples of Romanian Folk Literature in Areas over the Dniester"), a communication for the [[Cluj-Napoca|Cluj]]-based scientific review ''Anuarul Arhivei de Folclor''. It notably samples Transnistrian mournful lyrics about [[Conscription in Russia|forced recruitment]] during the [[History of the Russo-Turkish wars|Russo-Turkish Wars]].<ref>Băieșu, p.105</ref> That year, he carried out ethnographic interviews within the Romanian Transnistrian exile community, on behalf of the [[Romanian Academy]].<ref name="ansdincolo2"/><ref>{{ro icon}} Gheorghe Pavelescu, [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/bitstream/123456789/6857/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_BALP73_1939_007_010_012.pdf "Etnografia românească din Ardeal în ultimii douăzeci de ani (1919—1939)"], in ''[[Gând Românesc]]'', Nr. 10-12/1939, p.457–458 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> As argued by ethnographer Constantin Eretescu, such contributions made Smochină "the most significant researcher of folk culture in that area."<ref name="cemisc">{{ro icon}} Constantin Eretescu, [http://revistacultura.ro/nou/2011/01/miscellanea-ethnologica/ "Miscellanea ethnologica"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 308, January 2011</ref>
His main activity in advancing the cause of Transnistrians was creating the Association of Transnistrian Romanians. It was designed to give further support to the Romanian refugees from that region, who were estimated at 20,000.<ref name="ck181"/> Smochină himself estimated that there were in all some 1,200,000 Romanians living in the Moldavian ASSR, forming 80% of the native population—this remains the highest such estimate, significantly ahead of the number advanced in the 1910s by activist [[Alexis Nour]].<ref>Pântea, p.176–177</ref> By the late 1930s, Smochină was contributing to Iorga's summer school program in [[Vălenii de Munte]] town. Physician [[G. Brătescu]], who attended these conferences as an adolescent, notes that Smochină gave "frightening accounts" of life in Transnistria.<ref name="gb59">[[G. Brătescu]], ''Ce-a fost să fie. Notații autobiografice'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2003, p.59. {{ISBN|973-50-0425-9}}</ref> Brătescu, who was also being introduced to [[Romanian Communist Party]] propaganda, also recalled that local communists dismissed Smochină's discourse as "fabrications by a provocateur, a bitter enemy of communism."<ref name="gb59"/>
===Antonescu's adviser=== Smochină's political and scientific activities were affected by the 1940 [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia]]. He escaped Chișinău in time, but his research material was left behind. The [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] regime declared him a ''[[persona non grata]]'', and [[Censorship in the Soviet Union|Soviet censorship]] repossessed and banned all of his published volumes.<ref name="cemisc"/> Smochină was to accuse the Soviet authorities of vandalizing the Chișinău printing press where he was publishing a voluminous scientific work, reportedly lost in the process.<ref name="id18"/> As a representative of the Transnistrian community, Smochină attached himself the Bessarabian Circle of Bucharest, presided over by [[Gherman Pântea]].<ref>Constantin (2010), p.91</ref> Also escaping the occupation, Claudia joined her father in Bucharest, where she married the Bessarabian-born linguist Diomid Strungaru.<ref name="cineseteme"/>
The family was in Bucharest in 1940, when the loss of [[Northern Transylvania]] plunged Romania into a political crisis. Smochină deeply admired ''[[Conducător]]'' [[Ion Antonescu]], who was Romania's dictatorial ruler from 1941 to 1944. The Transnistrian ethnographer preserved Antonescu's image as a "great lover of the nation" and an "honest man", particularly since Antonescu promised to revisit the Bessarabian-Transnistrian issue "with an axe".<ref name="id17"/> According to his memoirs, Smochină accompanied the ''Conducător'' on all of his visits to [[Nazi Germany]], where Antonescu reportedly imposed respect on German dictator [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref name="id17"/> At that time, Romania formalized its alliance with the [[Axis Powers]] and, in summer 1941, joined Germany's [[Operation Barbarossa|sudden attack on the Soviet Union]]. During the early stages of war, the Romanian leader appointed Smochină his personal adviser on the issue of Transnistria.<ref name="ic(10)238"/> His work for that year included the brochure ''Masacrele de la Nistru'' ("Massacres on the Dniester"), which accused the Soviets of committing various crimes against the Romanian populace.<ref name="ppgmemento!"/>
''Moldova Nouă'' was reestablished, with the subtitle ''Revistă de studii și cercetări transnistriene'' ("Review of Transnistrian Studies and Research"),<ref>Kulikovski & Șcelcikova, p.247. See also Constantin (2010), p.238</ref> publishing Smochină's [[German language|German-language]] work ''Die Rumänen zwischen Dnjestr und Bug'' ("The Romanians between the Dniester and the [[Southern Bug|Bug]]"), detailing the activities of Romanian boyars in "New Russia".<ref>{{fr icon}} Matei Cazacu, [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/cmr_0008-0160_1993_num_34_1_2347 "Familles de la noblesse roumaine au service de la Russie, XVe-XIXe siècles"], in ''[[Cahiers du Monde Russe et Soviétique]]'', Nr. 1-2/1993, p.216, 225 (republished by [http://www.persee.fr/web/support/soon_available ''Persée'' Scientific Journals] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120908132757/http://www.persee.fr/web/support/soon_available |date=2012-09-08 }})</ref> The magazine went out of print in 1942, but was replaced with the anonymously titled ''Transnistria'', published by Smochină until 1944.<ref name="id15"/>
His son Alexandru N. Smochină also had contributions to the wartime press, writing for [[Octavian Tăslăuanu]]'s nationalist review ''Dacia''.<ref name="ansdincolo2"/> He graduated from Iași Law School in 1940, while also completing [[officer training]].<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/> Following the reconquest of Bessarabia and the crossing of the Dniester, the Antonescu regime created a [[Transnistria Governorate]], which had [[Gheorghe Alexianu]] as the chief administrator and Gherman Pântea as the Mayor of [[Odessa]]. Alexandru Smochină was taken off active duty and made Second Prefect of Transnistria's [[Berezovca County, Transnistria|County Berezovca]].<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/>
However, Smochină Sr. found himself ill at ease with the Governorate's military and civilian administration, noting instances where Governor Alexianu and [[Gendarmerie (Romania)|Gendarmerie]] commander [[Constantin Vasiliu]] derided their Bessarabian subordinates.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.96</ref> Additionally, Smochină described the [[1941 Odessa massacre]], ordered by Antonescu in retaliation for a supposed Jewish plot against the Romanian command, as a grave error on the Romanians' part: as he noted, both he and Pântea had been informed that the building supposedly bombed by Jewish activists had in fact been mined by the retreating Soviets.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.103, 105</ref> Smochină also claimed that Ion Antonescu saw Hitler's war on the "three occult forces" (Jews, Freemasons and the [[Catholic Church]]) as a "great mistake" which could lose Germany the war.<ref name="id17"/> In Smochină's account, the ''Conducător'' had gone on to state: "[Hitler] could have easily lured the Jewry on his side, and after the war he'd have been able to wrestle with it, but not in this destructive manner, that one is not humane."<ref name="id17"/>
On July 2, 1942, Smochină was made an honorary member of the Romanian Academy.<ref name="ppgmemento!"/><ref>Datcu, p.15. See also Constantin (2010), p.238</ref> He was at the time working under anthropologist [[Traian Herseni]], involved in a large [[interdisciplinary]] effort to collect and systematize the folkloric creation of Transnistrian Romanians; his contribution was featured in Gheorghe Pavelescu's 1943 monograph ''Aspecte din spiritualitatea românilor transnistrieni: Credințe și obiceiuri'' ("Aspects of Romanian Transnistrian Spirituality: Beliefs and Customs").<ref>Băieșu, p.108–109</ref> The investigation also aimed to react against decades of [[USSR anti-religious campaign (1928–1941)|Soviet anti-religious campaigns]], and consciously excluded all folklore which showed Soviet-era influences.<ref>Băieșu, p.109</ref> In Tiraspol, Alexandru Smochină took up a like-minded project, founding the Moldavian Circle, which disseminated propaganda and popularized Romanian historiography.<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/>
For a while, Smochină Sr. was in the [[Crimea]], helping Romanian historian [[Gheorghe I. Brătianu]] to recover the letters addressed by his ancestor, Ion Brătianu, to [[Nicholas I of Russia]].<ref name="id17"/> He maintained contacts with local [[Russians]] and helped [[anti-communist]] surgeon Pavel Chasovnikov (Ceasovnicov) in receiving Romanian citizenship rights.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.138</ref> In his native area of Dubăsari, the scholar played host to Romanian students coming in from Bucharest and from Odessa's [[Romanian Cultural Institute]].<ref name="viahcaract"/>
===Communist repression=== By early 1944, the Axis had been dealt major defeats on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]], and the Soviets began their menacing [[Dnieper–Carpathian Offensive]]. The change of fortunes alarmed Bessarabian and Transnistrian activists: Smochină, Halippa and Boldur joined others in a diplomatic effort to convince the [[Allies of World War II|Western Allies]] that Bessarabia needed to be part of Romania, but the military situation prevented them from ever leaving Romania.<ref>Constantin (2008), p.46–47</ref> The subsequent [[Battle of Romania]] evacuated Romanian administration from Transnistria, Bessarabia, and even parts of Moldavia-proper. In August 1944, [[King Michael's Coup]] toppled Antonescu and took Romania out of the Axis. Smochină claimed to have personally been helping Antonescu in negotiating a [[separate peace]] with the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Powers]], days before the regime fell.<ref name="id18"/> After Antonescu's arrest, the former Transnistria adviser lived a secluded life, and focused on writing his works of history.<ref name="ic(10)238"/>
When a [[Communist Romania|Romanian communist regime]] came into existence, Smochină's works were [[Censorship in Communist Romania|officially censored]], and the remaining copies were tracked down and confiscated.<ref name="id18"/> According to Popescu Gogan, he was especially sought after for his ''Masacrele de la Nistru''.<ref name="ppgmemento!"/> The [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupiers]] picked up Smochină Jr., who was at the time living in Romania with his wife and daughter, and working as an attorney.<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/> According to one account, this was case of clerical error: they deported Alexandru to the [[Gulag]] only because they mistook him for his father.<ref name="ic(10)238"/> The story was contradicted by more detailed research into the period. It surfaced that Alexandru was interrogated for his wartime activities in Berezovca and Tiraspol. He was thus formally accused of promoting [[Romanianization]], of spying against the Soviet state, and of causing some 964 million [[Soviet ruble|руб]] of damage to Transnistria; found guilty, he was given 25 years of hard labor, to be served in [[Amur Oblast]].<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/>
Smochină Sr. went into hiding. He used aliases and tried to make himself lost in the [[Carpathian Mountains]], but was tracked down by the repressive apparatus.<ref name="id18"/> He ended up in prison, and, as he recalled, was subjected to numerous beatings.<ref name="id18"/> His academician's title, his pension and his right of attending the [[Romanian Academy Library]] were all removed from him (''see [[List of purged members of the Romanian Academy]]'').<ref name="id18"/> His son-in-law, Diomid Strungaru, was stripped of all positions in academia, and had to work at a [[clothes iron]] factory.<ref name="cineseteme"/>
By 1955, with [[Destalinization]] in full swing, both Smochinăs were unceremoniously released. Alexandru was picked up from his place of exile, and dropped back to Romania as a released [[prisoner of war]], with no papers on him. (Since this rendered him effectively a [[nonperson]], he was forced to support himself by menial labor.)<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/> Smochină Sr. was kept under tight surveillance by the [[Securitate]] secret police, whose reports summarized his career in nationalist politics: "before the year 1944 he edited and managed various publications with [[Anti-Soviet agitation|anti-Soviet content]], drafted and printed a significant number of anti-Soviet books and generated large-scale propaganda efforts to support the Antonescu war through conferences, lectures and by other means."<ref>Constantin (2010), p.168</ref> Himself a former prisoner, Pântea was being pressured into becoming a Securitate informant on Transnistrian activities in Bucharest.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.168–176</ref>
In December 1959, Securitate agents intimidated Smochină from attending the funeral of former Bessarabian dignitary [[Grigore Cazacliu]], but, during interrogations, he denied knowledge (or feigned unawareness) of a plot to enthrone [[Constantin Tomescu]] as [[Metropolis of Bessarabia|Bessarabian Metropolitan]].<ref>Constantin (2010), p.153, 168–169</ref> Securitate sources claimed that the Bessarabian-Transnistrian underground was planning a set of measures to occur after the future "liberation of Bessarabia", and that Smochină was discussing a return to Chișinău.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.153, 168–171</ref> According to other such reports, Smochină was fully aware of being followed around by Securitate operatives, and tried to protect his friends by avoiding contact with them.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.153, 180</ref>
===Final activities=== Allegedly, Nichita Smochină found understanding from Romania's new [[National communism|national communist]] leader, [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]]. He claimed that, in 1965, Ceaușescu asked him to retrieve those documents which showed Antonescu's move to a separate peace; driven by a Securitate guard to [[Caransebeș]], where he had allegedly buried the evidence back in the late '40s, Smochină only recovered three empty crates.<ref name="id18"/> Ceaușescu allowed him to receive a new pension, but he was denied reintegration into the Academy, with the suggestion that such a move would dampen [[Romania–Russia relations]].<ref name="id18"/> These were openly tested by the Bessarabian community in February 1967, when Halippa presented Ceaușescu's [[State Council of Romania|Council of State]] with reports on the existence of oppressed Soviet Romanians. These included a polemical note by Smochină, who condemned the Soviet-endorsed delimitation of a "[[Moldovans|Moldovan people]]" in Bessarabia, and in general the ideology of "[[Moldovenism]]".<ref>Constantin (2008), p.49–50</ref> A month later, Halippa advanced Smochină's name among those of Bessarabians who could serve as specialists for the Romanian Communist Party's ISISP foundation of social science.<ref>Constantin (2008), p.51</ref>
Smochină was recovered by the Romanian and Soviet schools of [[Slavic studies|Slavistics]], commissioned for translations from Slavonic documents which were published by either the Romanian Academy or the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Moscow Academy of Sciences]].<ref name="ic(10)238"/> He was allowed back at the Academy Library, but still banned from authoring contributing original books of his own.<ref name="ppgmemento!"/> In the 1970s, he published articles in a specialized magazine based in [[Thessaloniki]], [[Greece]], and donated his documents and manuscripts to the [[National Archives of Romania]].<ref name="ic(10)238"/> Strungaru was also allowed back to work in universities, and Smochină moved in with him and Claudia.<ref name="cineseteme"/>
At that stage, exiled Bessarabians could profit from the relative tolerance of Romania's national communist system, and began organizing themselves into advocacy groups, even establishing links in the West. Smochină himself tried to mediate between the two competing factions: one represented by [[Ion Păscăluță]] (and supported by Halippa); the other headed by [[Anton Crihan]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Ion Constantin, [http://old.bmms.ro/continut/xhtml/ro/Revista_online/Nr.6_2009/Pantelimon_hailipa_exilul_3.html "Pantelimon Halippa și exilul românesc pentru cauza Basarabiei"], in ''Revista Biblioteca Bucureștilor'', Nr. 6/2009</ref>
Smochină died in Bucharest, on December 14, 1980.<ref>Constantin (2010), p.237; Datcu, p.18</ref> His work and life were again in public focus after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]] overthrew Ceaușescu. His main ethnographic research was featured in the 1996 anthology ''Românitatea transnistriană'' ("Transnistrian Romanianness"), published in Bucharest by Editura Semne.<ref>Băieșu, p.104, 112; Pântea, p.202</ref> On July 3, 1990, he was posthumously reinstated honorary Academy member.<ref name="id18"/>
Smochină is also remembered by the authorities of [[Moldova]], the Bessarabian state created by the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], where Alexandru Smochină was formally [[Rehabilitation (Soviet)|rehabilitated]] in 1996.<ref name="mttrnistreanul"/> [[President of Moldova|Moldovan President]] [[Mihai Ghimpu]] awarded Smochină Sr. posthumous [[Order of Honor (Moldova)|Order of Honor]] insignia in April 2010.<ref name="annistru"/><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.jurnal.md/ro/news/academicianul-smochina-distins-post-mortem-cu-ordinul-de-onoare-184967/ "Academicianul Smochină, distins post-mortem cu Ordinul de Onoare"], in ''[[Jurnal de Chișinău]]'', April 20, 2010</ref> Smochină is not honored in Transnistria-proper, which is ruled by a [[Political status of Transnistria|breakaway pro-Russian regime]]. Reportedly, Alexandru Smochină tried to visit his ancestral home in Mahala (where a ''Smokine'' family still lives), but was prevented from entering the premises by a group of local Russians.<ref name="cineseteme"/>
Nichita Smochină's memoirs (or ''Memorii'') were published, care of [[Editura Academiei]], in 2009 and ''Pagini din însemnările unui rebel. Academicianul Nichita Smochină'' were published, care of [[Editura Samia, Iași]], in 2012. The editor is Vlad Galin-Corini, son-in-law of Diomid Strungaru.<ref name="cineseteme"/> Commentators have described the book as a revelation, in particular for its detail on the various public figures whom the Transnistrian ethnologist had met before 1944.<ref name="cineseteme"/><ref>Constantin (2010), p.96, 103, 105, 138, 145–146; Datcu, ''passim''</ref> According to Galin-Corini, these works were also rejected by editors in Moldova, because they make brazen statements about Bessarabians who collaborated with the Soviets.<ref name="cineseteme"/>
