[[File:Winton-Train-Headboard-London-Liverpool-St-Stn-20090904.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The [[Headboard (train)|headboard]] worn by [[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|No. 60163 ''Tornado'']] from [[Harwich]] to [[Liverpool Street station]], the final leg of the Winton Train from [[Prague]]]] The '''Winton Train''' was a private [[passenger train]] that travelled from the [[Czech Republic]] to [[Great Britain]] in September 2009 in tribute to the wartime efforts of [[Nicholas Winton|Sir Nicholas Winton]], described as the 'British [[Oskar Schindler|Schindler]]' for his part in saving refugee children from [[Czechoslovakia]].
As a result of Sir Nicholas' efforts in the months leading up to the outbreak of [[World War II]] in 1939, a total of seven locomotives transported 669 Czechoslovak children of mainly Jewish heritage from Prague to safety in Great Britain.<ref name= 60Minutes>{{cite AV media |people=Simon, Bob (Correspondent) |date=27 April 2014 |series= 60 Minutes |title=Saving the Children |medium=Television Production Transcript |language=English |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/saving-the-children-on-eve-of-world-war-11-60-minutes/ |access-date=19 May 2016 |publisher= CBS News}}</ref>
Sir Nicholas' [[kindertransport]] efforts remained largely unrecognised until 1988, when they came to public attention after his wife found a scrapbook in their attic documenting the details. Only then did the individuals whom Winton arranged to have transported to safety as children learn the story of how they survived the Holocaust. As the majority of 'Winton's Children' (as they came to be known) were Jewish, it is believed this saved them from [[The Holocaust|certain death]] had they stayed in Czechoslovakia. As of 2009, the direct descendants of Winton's Children numbered over 5000 people.
The 2009 tribute Winton Train carried some of the individuals Sir Nicholas arranged to have transported to safety in 1939, along with their families, as it retraced the original kindertransport route taken by the trains on which they rode as children to safety in Great Britain 70 years earlier. The Winton Train departed on 1 September 2009, the 70th anniversary of the eighth, and intended last, train arranged by Winton to carry children to safety but was prevented from doing so due to the outbreak of World War II on that very day.<ref name=60Minutes /> It departed from [[Praha hlavní nádraží|Prague Main railway station]] and travelled through [[Germany]] and the [[Netherlands]]. After a transfer by ferry to [[Harwich]], the journey resumed by train again to arrive in London's [[Liverpool Street station]] on 4 September, where it was met by the 100-year-old Sir Nicholas himself. For the journey across mainland Europe, the train was formed of period carriages and was hauled by historically authentic [[steam locomotives]], while the British leg was hauled by [[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|60163 ''Tornado'']], a brand-new, main-line British steam locomotive completed in 2008, along with carriages that were constructed in the 1950s.
The tribute train was the centrepiece of a wider cultural awareness project known as 'Inspiration by Goodness', organised by the [[Czech government]].
==Background==
===Original Winton trains=== Between March and September 1939, the months leading up to the outbreak of [[World War II]], [[Nicholas Winton]], a 29-year-old [[Christian]] [[United Kingdom|British]] [[stockbroker]] whose parents were of German Jewish descent,<ref name=Telegraph4Sep09/><ref name=AP4Sep09/><ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/> organised eight trains to transport mainly [[Jewish]] Czech and Slovak refugee children from Czechoslovakia to homes in [[United Kingdom|Britain]].<ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/> The Winton trains were part of a wider British rescue effort from various other countries across Europe, known as the [[Kindertransport]]s.
[[File:Wintons Prague memorial by Flor Kent - 1.jpg|thumb|right|A statue of [[Nicholas Winton|Sir Nicholas Winton]] by [[Flor Kent]], unveiled in [[Praha hlavní nádraží|Prague Main railway station]] on 1 September 2009, the day of departure of the Winton tribute train. The girl is modelled on the granddaughter of a girl saved by one of Winton's original trains in 1939.<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/>]] In 1939, Winton cancelled a trip to a Swiss holiday resort to go to Prague, having heard of a growing refugee crisis resulting from the [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia]] from a friend. His friend was working in the [[List of diplomatic missions of the United Kingdom|British embassy]] for the British Committee for Refugees from Czechoslovakia, which was already working to help adults escape from [[Czechoslovakia]].<ref name=AP4Sep09/><ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/> When Winton learned that refugee children could not leave unless accompanied, he decided to arrange their evacuation to Britain.<ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/> While the Winton evacuations later became known by the collective label of the children's [[Kindertransport]]s, which were officially being organised elsewhere in other countries, no official Kindertransports had been arranged in Prague at that time.<ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/><ref name=BBCEvacueesThankSaviour4Sep09/>
Winton organised the transfer of the children from the Nazi-appointed [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]] to homes in Britain, in the process arranging the necessary bonds and permits for their departure, and finding the families in Britain who would receive the children.<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/> Winton and a team identified those children most at risk from the thousands of refugees driven south following the Nazi invasion of the [[Sudetenland]].<ref name=BBCEvacueesThankSaviour4Sep09/> For each child to be accepted, British officials required a confirmed [[Foster care|foster home]] and a [[£]]50 guarantee.<ref name=AP4Sep09/> Winton returned to Great Britain in March to arrange the reception of the children, but his task was hampered by the fact that the [[Evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II|domestic evacuation of children]] was already occurring, and places were hard to find.
Beginning in March, Winton organised eight trains, which in total transported 669 mainly Jewish children from Nazi occupied Czechoslovakia to Great Britain.<ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09/><ref name=A1TrustWintonTrain/><ref name=WintonIntro2Feb09/> A ninth and final train with 250 children on board was stopped at the last minute, due to the outbreak of the war.<ref name=BBCRetracing31Aug09>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8227929.stm |title=Retracing a life-saving journey |date=2009-08-31 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUsiRWPm?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8227929.stm |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Only two children on this ninth aborted train survived the war.<ref name=AP4Sep09/><ref>[http://arafp.homestead.com/wherearetheynow.html Tom Berman - September 2009]</ref><ref>[https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/50623/gissing.pdf;jsessionid=682ADBDE391D60277FF11F0AAB3F6E80?sequence=4 Vera Gissing Interview]</ref> According to [[Channel 4 News]] reporting on the 2009 Winton Train, "Sir Nicholas has said many times that the vision that haunts him most is the families waiting at Liverpool Street for the train that never arrived".<ref name=C4News4Sep09>{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/uk/winton+train+arrives+in+london/3331402 |title=Winton train arrives in London |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[Channel 4 News]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZ6fQ4U5?url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/uk/winton%20train%20arrives%20in%20london/3331402 |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The original trains left from [[Praha hlavní nádraží|Prague Wilson railway station]] (now Prague Main station).<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09/> While most of the children were met by their new families at London's [[Liverpool Street station]], some of the children got off the trains at Harwich, where they were placed with local families.<ref name=BBCEssex4Sep09>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/essex/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8238000/8238604.stm |title=The train that saved our lives |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[BBC Essex]] |work=BBC Local, People and Places, History |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZ5DHXvS?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/essex/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8238000/8238604.stm |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Few if any of the Winton children saw their parents again.<!--sources conflit - AP says few, others say none--><ref name=Telegraph4Sep09/><ref name=AP4Sep09/>
Winton's efforts did not come to public light until 1988, when his wife discovered papers in their loft, whereupon Winton began to publicly talk about his work, and he came to be known as the 'British Schindler', in comparison to [[Oskar Schindler]].<ref name=TelegraphProfile2Sep09>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/world-war-2/6125995/Nicholas-Winton-English-Schindler-Profile.html |title=Nicholas Winton, 'English Schindler': Profile |date=2009-09-02 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUx2UzBp?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/world-war-2/6125995/Nicholas-Winton-English-Schindler-Profile.html |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Sir Nicholas himself believed this was undeserved, because unlike Schindler, his life had never been in danger.<ref name=Telegraph4Sep09>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/world-war-2/6138441/Sir-Nicholas-Winton-the-British-Schindler-meets-the-Holocaust-survivors-he-helped-save.html |title=Sir Nicholas Winton, the 'British Schindler', meets the Holocaust survivors he helped save |author=Stephen Adams |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZD6aD6e?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/world-war-2/6138441/Sir-Nicholas-Winton-the-British-Schindler-meets-the-Holocaust-survivors-he-helped-save.html |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=AP4Sep09/>
===Inspiration by Goodness project=== [[File:Nicholas Winton in Prague.jpg|thumb|left|[[Nicholas Winton|Sir Nicholas Winton]] in Prague, October 2007]] A project to run a train in tribute to the original Winton trains was announced on 21 January 2008 as the ''Train Prague – London'' project, and the organisers were negotiating to have the train named after Sir Nicholas.<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09>{{cite web |url=http://www.wintontrain.eu/en/site/o-projektu/op-projekt-winton-train.htm |title=Winton Train Project |date=n.d. |publisher=The Winton Train project |work=Official website, About the Project |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUfMtfPw?url=http://www.wintontrain.eu/en/site/o-projektu/op-projekt-winton-train.htm |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The train was run by [[Czech Railways]] and sponsored by the [[Czech government]], with the project being dedicated to their holding of the [[Presidency of the Council of the European Union]] from January to June 2009.<ref name=A1TrustWintonTrain/> The train was part of a wider project encompassing social and cultural events along the route to "inspire young people through the deeds of Nicholas Winton", and with the theme of "Inspiration by Goodness", it incorporated art, film, photographic and literary contests by university students and school children.<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09/>
The project was to follow on from the work of documentary film maker [[Matej Mináč]] about Sir Nicholas, including his new film project ''Nicky's Family''.<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09/> While travelling on the train, Mináč filmed scenes for a new version of the Winton story.<ref name=BBCEvacueesThankSaviour4Sep09>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8237231.stm |title=Czech evacuees thank their saviour |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZN4oZOc?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8237231.stm |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The [[Senate of the Czech Republic|Czech Senate]] President [[Přemysl Sobotka]] said of the project that it "should warn against rising extremism and anti-Semitism in Europe and in the world".<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/>
==2009 Winton Train==
===Journey=== [[File:486.007 locomotive.jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive No. 486.007, used in the Czech Republic (front)]] [[File:Albatros 1.jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive No. 498.022, used in the Czech Republic (rear)]] [[File:DRG 41 018.jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive No. 41 018, used in Germany]] [[File:DRG 41 360 im Landschaftspark Duisburg-Nord (9608-10).jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive No. 41 360, used in Germany]] [[File:Winton Train in Nederland.jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive No. 01 1075 with the Winton Train passing [[Arnhem Velperpoort railway station]] in the Netherlands]] [[File:Winton-Train-London-Liverpool-St-Stn-20090904a.jpg|thumb|right|Locomotive [[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|No. 60163 ''Tornado'']] arriving with the Winton Train in London [[Liverpool Street station]], England]] The motive power for the train journey was provided by six different [[steam locomotives]] in total, two as a [[Double-heading|double-headed]] train in the [[Czech Republic]] due to the terrain, two in [[Germany]], one in the [[Netherlands]] and one in [[Great Britain]]. The entire journey was scheduled to take four days, involving a European train leg, a crossing by the passengers on a ferry and a British train leg. It covered a distance of {{convert|1296|km|mi}}, of which {{convert|1139|km|mi}} was the train journey across [[mainland Europe]].<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09>{{cite web |url=http://palubnidenik.wintontrain.eu/en/historical-train/ |title=Historical Train |date=n.d. |publisher=The Winton Train project |work=Official website, Train's Log |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUl4Aevl?url=http://palubnidenik.wintontrain.eu/en/historical-train/ |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On 1 September the train departed [[Praha hlavní nádraží|Prague Main railway station]].<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09>{{cite web |last=ČTK |title=Train in honour of Jewish children rescuer Winton leaves Prague |url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/train-in-honour-of-jewish-children-rescuer-winton-leaves-prague/395346 |date=2009-09-02 |work=České noviny |publisher=Neris s.r.o. |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUgoovgC?url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/train-in-honour-of-jewish-children-rescuer-winton-leaves-prague/395346 |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> On this first day it travelled to the German city of [[Nuremberg]], crossing the Czech - German border at [[Furth im Wald]] in the [[Bavarian Forest]]. The following day, the train was to travel across Germany to [[Cologne]], via [[Frankfurt am Main]].<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> Instead of Frankfurt however, it travelled via [[Wiesbaden]] and the right bank of the [[River Rhine]]. On the third day, the train arrived on the [[North Sea]] coast at the Dutch ferry port, [[Hook of Holland]], crossing the Dutch - German border at [[Emmerich am Rhein]] and passing through the [[Netherlands]] via [[Rotterdam]].<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> The passengers disembarked the train to cross the North Sea to Great Britain overnight on the [[Stena Line]] ferry ''Stena Britannica'' to [[Harwich]], a port in the [[East of England]] on the country boundary between [[Essex]] and [[Suffolk]]. The British train journey formed the fourth day of the journey, travelling from Harwich to the London terminus of [[Liverpool Street station]].<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/>
On this final day the train departed [[Harwich International railway station]] at 09:12am.<ref name=BBCEssex4Sep09/> It travelled via {{rws|Colchester}} and {{rws|Chelmsford}}, arriving at Liverpool Street station at 10:37 on Platform 10.<ref name=A1TrustWintonTrain/> Platform 10 was the platform number that the original Winton trains had used,<ref name=Telegraph4Sep09/> although the platform numbers were reconfigured in the 1980s as part of the station's redevelopment.
Sir Nicholas, now 100 years old, met the train at Liverpool Street as guest of honour.<ref name=A1TrustWintonTrain/><ref name=BBCWWIIRescue4Sep09/> On greeting the passengers, Winton said "It's wonderful to see you all after 70 years; don't leave it quite so long until we meet here again.
At Liverpool Street Station all guests and train passengers were conveyed by a fleet of 70-year-old London buses to the Czech Embassy for the Official Reception. The special transport was organised by the Autofest Organisation on behalf of the [[Bohemia Transport Muzeum]] with special help from the [[London Bus Preservation Trust]] and the Newman family of [[Ensign Buses]].
"<ref name=AP4Sep09>{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hSR5n138ibL_4FPUNWIb9Ndf8ZbgD9AGN7OO0 |title=Jews who escaped Nazis as kids recreate train trip |author=Karolina Tagaris |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZ2nMQFU?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hSR5n138ibL_4FPUNWIb9Ndf8ZbgD9AGN7OO0 |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=BBCWWIIRescue4Sep09>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8238104.stm |title=WWII rescue train trip recreated |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZ73vbHj?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8238104.stm |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Also at Liverpool Street to meet the train was [[Štefan Füle]], the Czech Minister for European Affairs, and a former Czech ambassador to Britain.<ref name=RadioPrague4Sep09>{{cite news |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/article/119951 |title=Winton Train arrives in London for emotional reunion after 70 years |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[Radio Prague]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZB4B5fp?url=http://www.radio.cz/en/article/119951 |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Motive power and rolling stock=== Travelling through the Czech Republic from [[Prague]] to [[Furth im Wald]], the train was double-headed by locomotives No. 486.007 and 498.022,<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> with 486.007 leading as the train left Prague.<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/> No. 486.007, known as the ''Green Anton'' is a preserved steam locomotive built in 1936 and based in [[Vrútky]], Slovakia, owned by [[Železnice Slovenskej republiky|Slovak Republic Railways]] (ŽSR).<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> It is one of the [[:de:ČSD-Baureihe 486.0]] class, and has a green livery. No. 498.022, which is one of the [[:de:ČSD-Baureihe 498.0]] class, has a blue livery and is owned by [[Czech Railways]], who store it at [[Libeň]] in Prague, Czech Republic.<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/>
Travelling through Germany from [[Furth im Wald]] to [[Emmerich am Rhein]], the train was hauled by locomotive No. 41 018. No. 41 018 is a preserved steam locomotive built in 1939 and based at the [[Augsburg Railway Park]] railway museum in [[Augsburg]], Bavaria. It is one of the locomotive class [[DRG Class 41]], and it is owned by DG München.<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> From [[Linz am Rhein]] to Cologne, a second locomotive, No. 41 360 was attached.
As the train travelled through the Netherlands from [[Emmerich am Rhein]] to [[Hook of Holland]], it was hauled by Locomotive No. 01 1075. No. 01 1075 is a preserved steam locomotive built in 1940 and based at the [[Stoom Stichting Nederland]] (SSN) railway museum in Rotterdam.<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> It is one of the locomotive class [[DRG Class 01.10]].
Travelling through England (from [[Harwich]] to [[London]]), the train was hauled by [[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|No. 60163 ''Tornado'']], a British mainline steam locomotive built in 2008 by the [[A1 Steam Locomotive Trust]], the construction of which began in 1994 and was completed in 2008.<ref name=A1TrustWintonTrain>{{cite web |url=http://www.a1steam.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=333:the-winton-train&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=123 |title=The Winton Train |date=2009-08-30 |publisher=[[A1 Locomotive Trust]] |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUeNJrKG?url=http://www.a1steam.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=333:the-winton-train&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=123 |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The passenger rolling stock for the European leg from Prague to Hook of Holland comprised nine historic railway carriages of Hungarian and German origin, with a capacity for 240 passengers.<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/> The train included the blue liveried state luxury saloon carriage of [[Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk]], the first president of [[Czechoslovakia]], which entered service on 7 March 1930, Masaryk's 80th birthday.<ref name=WintonTrainLog2Sep09/>
For the British leg, behind ''Tornado'' and her [[Maroon (color)|maroon]] [[Support coach (UK steam locomotive)|support coach]], the train was headed by ''Pegasus'', a cream and brown [[Pullman train (UK)|Pullman Bar Car]] incorporating the Trianon Bar, followed by the historic 1950s built red and cream [[Royal Scot (passenger train)|''The Royal Scot'']] rake of [[British Railways Mark 1]] passenger coaches of [[Riviera Trains]].<ref name=BBCWWIIRescue4Sep09/> ''Pegasus'' was built in 1951 for the famous [[Golden Arrow (train)|''Golden Arrow'']] boat train, and later rebuilt for heritage mainline use.<ref name=StatesmanRailPullmanCarriages4Sep09>{{cite web |url=http://statesmanrail.com/pullman_carriages.html |title=The Statesman Land Cruise Train |date=n.d. |publisher=Statesman Rail Ltd |work=statesmanrail.com, Pullman Carriages |accessdate=2009-09-05 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jZ8SpEch?url=http://statesmanrail.com/pullman_carriages.html |archivedate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Passengers=== The 2009 Winton train carried 170 passengers, including 22 of those originally rescued, who came to be known as 'Winton's Children'.<ref name=C4News4Sep09/><ref name=BBCWWIIRescue4Sep09 /> Passengers included the first, second, or even third generation of descendants of the original children rescued by Sir Nicholas.<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09/> The descendants of the children Sir Nicholas rescued had by 2009 grown to number 5,000 people.<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/><ref name=WintonIntro2Feb09>{{cite web |url=http://www.wintontrain.eu/en/site/nicholas-winton/nw-intro.htm |title=Intro |date=n.d. |publisher=The Winton Train project |work=Official website, Nicholas Winton section |accessdate=2009-09-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jUsOMluN?url=http://www.wintontrain.eu/en/site/nicholas-winton/nw-intro.htm |archivedate=2009-09-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Passengers on the 2009 train also included Sir Nicholas's daughter Barbara.<ref name=CeskeNoviny1Sep09/> Other survivors who did not travel on the reunion train instead met it at Liverpool Street.<ref name=AP4Sep09/>
==Subsequent projects== It was the hope of the project to follow up the 2009 Winton Train to London with other Winton Trains to other European cities, and for it to become a tradition.<ref name=WintonAbout2Feb09/> In May 2011, an exhibition entitled ''Winton's Trains'' opened in London at Liverpool Street station.<ref name=CZembassy2011>{{cite news |url=http://www.mzv.cz/london/en/what_s_new/winton_s_trains_exhibition_opened_in.html |title=Winton´s Trains exhibition opened in London |date=2011-06-03 |publisher=Embassy of the Czech Republic in London |accessdate=2012-11-17}}</ref>
